name: Öko-Institut e.V.
goal:
The Öko-Institut is one of Europe's leading independent research and consulting institutions for a sustainable future. Since its foundation in 1977, the Institute has been developing the foundations and strategies for implementing the vision of sustainable development globally, nationally and locally.
At its three locations in Freiburg, Darmstadt and Berlin, the institute employs more than 170 people, including around 120 scientists. In 2018, they worked on more than 380 national and international projects in the following fields: chemicals management and technology assessment; energy and climate; emission and radiation protection; agriculture and biodiversity; sustainability in consumption, mobility, resource management and companies; nuclear technology and plant safety as well as law, politics and governance.
Based on value-oriented scientific research, the Öko-Institut advises decision-makers from politics, business and civil society. Since its foundation, the institute has been working interdisciplinary and transdisciplinary - with partners from business, science and civil society - in cooperative projects and network structures, where this makes sense in terms of questions.
The most important clients include federal and state ministries, companies and the European Union. The Institute is also active for non-governmental organisations and environmental associations.
The Öko-Institut is a non-profit association. The Institute finances its work primarily through third-party funds for projects. In addition, contributions and donations from around 2,000 members form the basis for independent research. The annual turnover is about 18 million euros.
interests: Agriculture and Rural Development, Business and Industry, Climate Action, Consumers, Energy, Environment, Maritime affairs and fisheries, Research and innovation, Trans-European Networks, Transport
euInitiatives:
Oeko-Institut is performing service contracts resulting from official tender procedures of various DGs (in particular DG Energy, Climate Action, DG Environment, DG Transport, DG GROW) as well as the European Environment Agency and the European Parliament. Furthermore, Oeko-Institut participates in EU research programmes (e.g. HORIZON 2020).
Specifc intiatives followed as part of such contracts are
- EU Long-term low GHG emission strategy
- Regulation (EU) 2018/1999 on the governance of the Energy Union
- Regulation (EU) No 517/2014 on fluorinated greenhouse gases
- Amending Regulation (EU) 2015/757 in order to take appropriate account of the global data collection system for ship fuel oil consumption data
- 7th Environmental Action Programme
- Strategic Dialogue on Sustainable Raw Materials for Europe (STRADE)
- Compliance Promotion Initiative to assess the implementation of Directive 2000/53/EU on end-of life vehicles (the ELV Directive) with emphasis on the end-of-life vehicles with unknown whereabouts
- Directive 2006/66EC on batteries and accumulators and waste batteries and accumulators
- EU Chemicals Legislation
- Ecodesign / energy labelling regulations and strategy for the EU Ecolabel
